Title: System Dynamics
Article:
System dynamics (SD) is an approach to understanding the nonlinear behaviour of complex systems over time using stocks, flows, internal feedback loops, table functions and time delays.[1]

System dynamics is a methodology and mathematical modeling technique to frame, understand, and discuss complex issues and problems. Originally developed in the 1950s to help corporate managers improve their understanding of industrial processes, SD is currently being used throughout the public and private sector for policy analysis and design.[2]

Convenient graphical user interface (GUI) system dynamics software developed into user friendly versions by the 1990s and have been applied to diverse systems. SD models solve the problem of simultaneity (mutual causation) by updating all variables in small time increments with positive and negative feedbacks and time delays structuring the interactions and control. The best known SD model is probably the 1972 The Limits to Growth. This model forecast that exponential growth of population and capital, with finite resource sources and sinks and perception delays, would lead to economic collapse during the 21st century under a wide variety of growth scenarios.

System dynamics is an aspect of systems theory as a method to understand the dynamic behavior of complex systems. The basis of the method is the recognition that the structure of any system, the many circular, interlocking, sometimes time-delayed relationships among its components, is often just as important in determining its behavior as the individual components themselves. Examples are chaos theory and social dynamics. It is also claimed that because there are often properties-of-the-whole which cannot be found among the properties-of-the-elements, in some cases the behavior of the whole cannot be explained in terms of the behavior of the parts.

System dynamics was created during the mid-1950s[3] by Professor Jay Forrester of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In 1956, Forrester accepted a professorship in the newly formed MIT Sloan School of Management. His initial goal was to determine how his background in science and engineering could be brought to bear, in some useful way, on the core issues that determine the success or failure of corporations. Forrester's insights into the common foundations that underlie engineering, which led to the creation of system dynamics, were triggered, to a large degree, by his involvement with managers at General Electric (GE) during the mid-1950s. At that time, the managers at GE were perplexed because employment at their appliance plants in Kentucky exhibited a significant three-year cycle. The business cycle was judged to be an insufficient explanation for the employment instability. From hand simulations (or calculations) of the stock-flow-feedback structure of the GE plants, which included the existing corporate decision-making structure for hiring and layoffs, Forrester was able to show how the instability in GE employment was due to the internal structure of the firm and not to an external force such as the business cycle. These hand simulations were the start of the field of system dynamics.[2]

During the late 1950s and early 1960s, Forrester and a team of graduate students moved the emerging field of system dynamics from the hand-simulation stage to the formal computer modeling stage. Richard Bennett created the first system dynamics computer modeling language called SIMPLE (Simulation of Industrial Management Problems with Lots of Equations) in the spring of 1958. In 1959, Phyllis Fox and Alexander Pugh wrote the first version of
DYNAMO (DYNAmic MOdels), an improved version of SIMPLE, and the system dynamics language became the industry standard for over thirty years. Forrester published the first, and still classic, book in the field titled Industrial Dynamics in 1961.[2]

From the late 1950s to the late 1960s, system dynamics was applied almost exclusively to corporate/managerial problems. In 1968, however, an unexpected occurrence caused the field to broaden beyond corporate modeling. John F. Collins, the former mayor of Boston, was appointed a visiting professor of Urban Affairs at MIT. The result of the Collins-Forrester collaboration was a book titled Urban Dynamics. The Urban Dynamics model presented in the book was the first major non-corporate application of system dynamics.[2] In 1967, Richard M. Goodwin published the first edition of his paper "A Growth Cycle",[4] which was the first attempt to apply the principles of system dynamics to economics. He devoted most of his life teaching what he called "Economic Dynamics", which could be considered a precursor of modern Non-equilibrium economics.[5]

The second major noncorporate application of system dynamics came shortly after the first. In 1970, Jay Forrester was invited by the Club of Rome to a meeting in Bern, Switzerland. The Club of Rome is an organization devoted to solving what its members describe as the "predicament of mankind"—that is, the global crisis that may appear sometime in the future, due to the demands being placed on the Earth's carrying capacity (its sources of renewable and nonrenewable resources and its sinks for the disposal of pollutants) by the world's exponentially growing population. At the Bern meeting, Forrester was asked if system dynamics could be used to address the predicament of mankind. His answer, of course, was that it could. On the plane back from the Bern meeting, Forrester created the first draft of a system dynamics model of the world's socioeconomic system. He called this model WORLD1. Upon his return to the United States, Forrester refined WORLD1 in preparation for a visit to MIT by members of the Club of Rome. Forrester called the refined version of the model WORLD2. Forrester published WORLD2 in a book titled World Dynamics.[2]

The primary elements of system dynamics diagrams are feedback, accumulation of flows into stocks and time delays.

As an illustration of the use of system dynamics, imagine an organisation that plans to introduce an innovative new durable consumer product.  The organisation needs to understand the possible market dynamics in order to design marketing and production plans.

In the system dynamics methodology, a problem or a system (e.g., ecosystem, political system or mechanical system) may be represented as a causal loop diagram.[6] A causal loop diagram is a simple map of a system with all its constituent components and their interactions. By capturing interactions and consequently the feedback loops (see figure below), a causal loop diagram reveals the structure of a system. By understanding the structure of a system, it becomes possible to ascertain a system's behavior over a certain time period.[7]

The causal loop diagram of the new product introduction may look as follows:

There are two feedback loops in this diagram.  The positive reinforcement (labeled R) loop on the right indicates that the more people have already adopted the new product, the stronger the word-of-mouth impact.  There will be more references to the product, more demonstrations, and more reviews.  This positive feedback should generate sales that continue to grow.

The second feedback loop on the left is negative reinforcement (or "balancing" and hence labeled B).  Clearly, growth cannot continue forever, because as more and more people adopt, there remain fewer and fewer potential adopters.

Both feedback loops act simultaneously, but at different times they may have different strengths.  Thus one might expect growing sales in the initial years, and then declining sales in the later years. However, in general a causal loop diagram does not specify the structure of a system sufficiently to permit determination of its behavior from the visual representation alone.[8]

Causal loop diagrams aid in visualizing a system's structure and behavior, and analyzing the system qualitatively. To perform a more detailed quantitative analysis, a causal loop diagram is transformed to a stock and flow diagram. A stock and flow model helps in studying and analyzing the system in a quantitative way; such models are usually built and simulated using computer software.

A stock is the term for any entity that accumulates or depletes over time.  A flow is the rate of change in a stock.

In this example, there are two stocks: Potential adopters and Adopters.  There is one flow: New adopters.  For every new adopter, the stock of potential adopters declines by one, and the stock of adopters increases by one.

The real power of system dynamics is utilised through simulation.  Although it is possible to perform the modeling in a spreadsheet, there are a variety of software packages that have been optimised for this.

The steps involved in a simulation are:

In this example, the equations that change the two stocks via the flow are:

List of all the equations in discrete time, in their order of execution in each year, for years 1 to 15 :

The dynamic simulation results show that the behaviour of the system would be to have growth in adopters that follows a classic s-curve shape.
The increase in adopters is very slow initially, then exponential growth for a period, followed ultimately by saturation.

To get intermediate values and better accuracy, the model can run in continuous time: we multiply the number of units of time and we proportionally divide values that change stock levels. In this example we multiply the 15 years by 4 to obtain 60 quarters, and we divide the value of the flow by 4.
Dividing the value is the simplest with the Euler method, but other methods could be employed instead, such as Runge–Kutta methods.

List of the equations in continuous time for trimesters = 1 to 60 :

System dynamics has found application in a wide range of areas, for example population, agriculture,[10]  epidemiological, ecological and economic systems, which usually interact strongly with each other.

System dynamics have various "back of the envelope" management applications. They are a potent tool to:

Computer software is used to simulate a system dynamics model of the situation being studied. Running "what if" simulations to test certain policies on such a model can greatly aid in understanding how the system changes over time.  System dynamics is very similar to systems thinking and constructs the same causal loop diagrams of systems with feedback.  However, system dynamics typically goes further and utilises simulation to study the behaviour of systems and the impact of alternative policies.[11]

System dynamics has been used to investigate resource dependencies, and resulting problems, in product development.[12][13]

A system dynamics approach to  macroeconomics, known as Minsky,  has been developed by the economist Steve Keen.[14] This has been used to successfully model world economic behaviour from the apparent stability of the Great Moderation to the sudden unexpected Financial crisis of 2007–08.

The figure above is a causal loop diagram of a system dynamics model created to examine forces that may be responsible for the growth or decline of life insurance companies in the United Kingdom. A number of this figure's features are worth mentioning. The first is that the model's negative feedback loops are identified by C's, which stand for Counteracting loops. The second is that double slashes are used to indicate places where there is a significant delay between causes (i.e., variables at the tails of arrows) and effects (i.e., variables at the heads of arrows). This is a common causal loop diagramming convention in system dynamics. Third, is that thicker lines are used to identify the feedback loops and links that author wishes the audience to focus on. This is also a common system dynamics diagramming convention. Last, it is clear that a decision maker would find it impossible to think through the dynamic behavior inherent in the model, from inspection of the figure alone.[15]

Summary: The meeting focused on the methodology and applications of System Dynamics (SD). It was noted that SD is a mathematical modeling technique developed in the 1950s by Professor Jay Forrester at MIT to understand complex systems' nonlinear behavior over time. Initially used for corporate management, it has since expanded to public policy analysis and design. The development of user-friendly GUI software in the 1990s facilitated its application across diverse systems. Key elements include feedback loops, stocks, flows, and time delays. The best-known model, 'The Limits to Growth,' predicted economic collapse due to exponential population growth and finite resources. SD's foundation lies in recognizing system structures' importance over individual components, with applications extending to chaos theory and social dynamics. Forrester's collaboration with GE managers highlighted internal firm structures as causes of employment instability, leading to formal computer modeling stages with languages like SIMPLE and DYNAMO. Non-corporate applications began with urban dynamics and extended to global socioeconomic issues through models like WORLD1 and WORLD2 for the Club of Rome. SD diagrams use causal loop diagrams for qualitative analysis and stock-and-flow diagrams for quantitative simulation, aiding in understanding system behaviors over time. Applications span various fields including economics, epidemiology, ecology, and resource management. Simulation software allows 'what if' scenarios to test policies' impacts on system behavior.

Meeting:
>>Systems Theorist: Good morning, everyone. It's wonderful to see you all here today. Our primary objective is to delve into the complexities of our current systems and identify actionable insights that can drive effective policy decisions.

>>Mathematical Modeler: Morning, everyone. Let's get started on exploring the intricate dynamics of our systems.

>>Policy Analyst: Hi all! I'm excited to discuss how we can turn these insights into effective policies.

>>Historian of Science: Hello, everyone. Looking forward to diving into the complexities together.

>>Systems Theorist: Right, let's outline some key areas we need to focus on today. We should make sure we're covering all relevant aspects comprehensively.

>>Mathematical Modeler: Absolutely. I think starting with a review of our current data would be beneficial so we know where we stand before diving deeper.

>>Policy Analyst: Agreed. Having a clear picture of our baseline is crucial for developing practical applications later on.

>>Historian of Science: Yes, indeed. And perhaps we could also consider historical precedents that might offer valuable lessons for our analysis?

>>Systems Theorist: That's an excellent point, Historian of Science. Historical context often provides critical insights into system behaviors over time.

>>Mathematical Modeler: Definitely. So, let's see if there are any patterns or anomalies in the data that align with past events or trends.

>>Policy Analyst: Well said, Mathematical Modeler. Understanding these patterns will help us craft more robust policies moving forward while avoiding past mistakes.

>>Historian of Science: Exactly! For instance, looking at how previous economic crises were managed could offer valuable lessons for our analysis. 
 >>Systems Theorist: You know, Jay Forrester's work at MIT really set the stage for system dynamics. It's amazing how we can use feedback loops and stocks and flows to model complex systems like corporate management or even global sustainability issues.

>>Mathematical Modeler: Absolutely! By using differential equations in our models, we can simulate different scenarios and see potential outcomes based on various inputs. It’s quite powerful.

>>Policy Analyst: Right, this approach is so useful for policy analysis too. We can predict how different policies might play out by modeling those feedback loops and time delays you mentioned.

>>Historian of Science: Forrester’s collaboration with General Electric was groundbreaking because he showed that internal structures could cause employment cycles independently of external economic factors. That was a huge insight back then!

>>Systems Theorist: And today, we’re applying these principles to tackle big challenges like climate change by understanding complex interactions within those systems.

>>Policy Analyst: Exactly! It helps us foresee unintended consequences before implementing policies so we can adjust our strategies accordingly.

>>Mathematical Modeler: Yes, creating detailed simulations with these models allows us to see how changes in one part affect the whole system over time—very useful for understanding complex interactions! 
 >>Systems Theorist: Think about feedback loops. They can either make things grow or shrink quickly, or they can help keep things stable. For example, positive feedback loops can lead to rapid changes, while negative feedback loops work to balance things out.

>>Policy Analyst: Right, and in policy-making, understanding these loops is key. Take public health—spreading good information about vaccines can increase vaccination rates quickly. On the other hand, managing resources during an outbreak often relies on negative feedback to keep things balanced.

>>Mathematical Modeler: Let's talk about stocks and flows. Stocks are like water in a bathtub—they build up or drain away over time. Flows are the rates at which this happens, like how fast the water fills or empties.

>>Historian of Science: Wait, can you explain that again? I'm not quite following.

>>Mathematical Modeler: Sure! Imagine a bathtub filling with water—that's your stock building up. The flow is how fast the water comes in from the faucet or goes out through the drain. Does that make sense?

>>Historian of Science: Yes, much clearer now. Thanks!

>>Mathematical Modeler: Great! We use differential equations to model how these stocks and flows change over time.

>>Historian of Science: Speaking of delays, historically during the Industrial Revolution, slow responses to labor demands caused big economic swings. This shows how important timely actions are in system dynamics today.

>>Systems Theorist: Exactly! Time delays can really affect a system's behavior, sometimes causing it to swing back and forth or even become unstable.

>>Policy Analyst (interrupting): That's interesting about supply chains! Are there any recent examples where these delays have caused major issues?

>>Systems Theorist: Absolutely! In today's supply chain management, delayed feedback on inventory levels can lead to overproduction or stockouts.

>>Policy Analyst: So understanding these feedback loops is crucial for managing systems effectively. 
 >>Systems Theorist: You know, one of the most notable applications of system dynamics is the 'Limits to Growth' study from the early 1970s. It used feedback loops and time delays to predict how exponential growth in population and capital would impact finite resources. It really showed how interconnected systems can lead to unexpected outcomes, like economic collapse under certain scenarios. What other fields do you think could benefit from similar modeling approaches?

>>Historian of Science: That's a great point. Speaking of historical context, remember Jay Forrester's work with John F. Collins in the late 1960s? They developed an urban dynamics model to tackle issues like housing shortages and unemployment in Boston. This was groundbreaking because it applied system dynamics to urban problems, showing how feedback loops within cities could lead to unintended consequences—something we still see today.

>>Mathematical Modeler: Absolutely! And if we look at healthcare, we can use these models to simulate disease spread and predict outcomes based on different interventions like vaccination or social distancing. It's all about quantifying impacts and making informed decisions.

>>Policy Analyst: Right, and in public policy, these models are invaluable for simulating environmental regulations' effects on pollution over time. By understanding these dynamics, policymakers can design interventions that balance economic growth with sustainability.

>>Historian of Science: Exactly! Forrester's urban dynamics model wasn't just about immediate issues but also long-term implications of policy decisions on city development. This laid the groundwork for modern urban planning tools. Are there any contemporary examples where such insights have directly influenced current policies?

>>Policy Analyst: Good question! System dynamics is crucial for evaluating long-term impacts of public health policies too. By modeling disease spread and intervention effects, we can identify strategies that reduce transmission rates while minimizing economic disruption.

>>Systems Theorist: And what if we applied this approach to education? By examining factors like student-teacher ratios, funding levels, and curriculum changes, we could predict their long-term effects on student performance and overall educational quality.

>>Mathematical Modeler: That's a solid idea! Similarly, applying system dynamics to climate change allows us to simulate interactions between greenhouse gas emissions and global temperature changes—helping us understand potential impacts of various mitigation strategies.

>>Policy Analyst: Definitely! In transportation planning too—by looking at traffic flow, public transit usage, and infrastructure development—we can predict long-term outcomes on congestion and mobility. This helps design more effective policies addressing systemic issues rather than just symptoms.

>>Systems Theorist: Renewable energy is another area ripe for this approach. By modeling energy production, consumption patterns, and technological advancements together, we could forecast long-term sustainability and economic viability—guiding better policy decisions.

>>Mathematical Modeler: And don't forget agriculture! Using differential equations to model crop growth under different conditions lets us quantify impacts from interventions like irrigation or fertilization on productivity.

>>Policy Analyst: Broadly speaking—system dynamics helps evaluate social policies by modeling interactions between welfare programs employment rates economic growth predicting how policy changes might influence societal well-being over time.

>>Historian of Science: Historically speaking—the principles behind system dynamics have been applied across many fields since Forrester's work began—but are there other notable examples where these models significantly influenced policy decisions or societal outcomes? 
 >>Mathematical Modeler: Let's talk about how user-friendly GUI software like SIMPLE and DYNAMO have changed simulation practices. These tools make model building and scenario testing much easier, which means more people can use them. This has led to wider applications in various fields.

>>Policy Analyst: Absolutely. For policy work, these tools are great for running 'what if' scenarios. We can test potential policies in a simulated environment before implementing them, saving time and resources. Has anyone here seen these simulations directly influence policy decisions?

>>Systems Theorist: Definitely. Making these tools available to more people has not only broadened their use but also improved our understanding of complex systems. We can see how different factors interact in real-time, which gives us a better idea of potential outcomes.

>>Historian of Science: Back in the 1990s, when SIMPLE and DYNAMO were developed, it was a game-changer. Suddenly, policymakers and other stakeholders could engage with complex models themselves. This broader access has really helped in making more informed decisions.

>>Mathematical Modeler: To put some numbers on it, these tools let us run detailed simulations that help in precise policy testing. This capability has definitely led to better decision-making processes.

>>Policy Analyst: I remember a project where we used these tools to simulate the impact of different public health policies on disease spread. It was amazing how accurately we could predict outcomes before any real-world implementation.

>>Systems Theorist: And from a systems perspective, seeing feedback loops and time delays play out in real-time is invaluable for making better decisions.

>>Mathematical Modeler: Exactly! For instance, using SIMPLE or DYNAMO to simulate disease spread by adjusting variables like vaccination rates can be incredibly precise.

>>Policy Analyst: Imagine if we didn't have such accessible tools; modeling would still be limited to experts alone. The availability of SIMPLE and DYNAMO has fundamentally changed our approach.

>>Historian of Science: Right, but let's not forget that while the historical context is important, what's really exciting is how we're using these tools today to tackle current challenges.

>>Systems Theorist: True! But do you think there's any downside? Sometimes I worry that having too many people involved might lead to oversimplified models or misinterpretations.

>>Policy Analyst: That's a good point. It's crucial that users understand the limitations of these models too. Maybe we need better training programs alongside the software?

>>Mathematical Modeler: Agreed. While it's great that more people can use these tools now, ensuring they know how to interpret the results correctly is just as important. 
 >>Systems Theorist: You know, from a systems perspective, the real power of system dynamics is in how it lets us see complex interactions and feedback loops that we might miss otherwise. But we have to be careful about oversimplifying things and making sure our data is spot on.

>>Policy Analyst: Absolutely. For policy-making, being able to simulate different scenarios and predict outcomes is a game-changer. It helps us avoid costly mistakes. But yeah, getting accurate data and not oversimplifying are big challenges.

>>Mathematical Modeler: Right, let's talk numbers. System dynamics can create detailed simulations based on various inputs and feedback loops. But the predictions are only as good as the data we feed into them and the assumptions we make.

>>Historian of Science: Exactly! Remember Jay Forrester's work with General Electric? It was groundbreaking but also showed how crucial accurate data is. How do we ensure we're not falling into the same traps today?

>>Systems Theorist: Imagine if we could use system dynamics to tackle issues like climate change or economic instability effectively. The potential is huge, but again, it all hinges on having reliable data and sound assumptions. How do we keep our models robust?

>>Policy Analyst: Good point. In policy-making, one of the biggest advantages is testing 'what if' scenarios before making any changes—this can save resources and prevent unintended consequences. But it's only effective if our data holds up.

>>Historian of Science: Looking back at Forrester’s early models reminds us that while system dynamics offers great insights, it demands precise data and well-thought-out assumptions. How do we avoid repeating those historical mistakes?

>>Mathematical Modeler: To add to that—using system dynamics for simulating different policy inputs can be very insightful. However, its accuracy depends heavily on having reliable data sources and solid assumptions.

>>Systems Theorist: So essentially—the benefits are significant, but we need to critically evaluate risks like oversimplification and reliance on accurate data inputs. How do we ensure our models stay reliable?

>>Policy Analyst: From a broader perspective—one practical benefit is testing 'what if' scenarios before implementing policies; it saves resources and prevents unintended consequences—but only if our data is solid.

>>Historian of Science: Historically speaking—you see—the evolution of system dynamics has always been tied closely with data accuracy reliability issues since Forrester’s time at GE faced similar problems too! How do current applications avoid repeating those pitfalls today? 
 >>Data Analyst: Let's look at our options. We need solid data and good feedback systems to make reliable decisions.

>>Project Manager: Yeah, if we add feedback loops and consider time delays, we can better handle potential issues. What do you think?

>>Policy Advisor: I agree with integrating feedback loops, but how do we ensure it's practical? From a policy standpoint, it has to work in the real world too.

>>Historian: You know, historically speaking, decisions that ignored practical implementation often led to big setbacks. Remember those early 20th-century economic policies? They were theoretically sound but failed miserably because they weren't practical. How can we avoid that?

>>Project Manager: Good point! Maybe we could start with a pilot program to test feasibility before going all in.

>>Data Analyst: That sounds like a plan. Starting small will give us the robust data and clear feedback mechanisms we need without risking too much upfront.
